definition: the surface of a leaf or bract which faces away from the stem, usually the lower surface but not always
leathery single-seeded fruit
radially symmetrical, usually of flowers (cf. zygomorphic)
the surface of a leaf or bract which faces towards the stem, usually the upper surface but not always
pressed closely towards the supporting surface, usually of hairs
arising in an unusual position, as with roots arising from the node of a stem or buds arising from a wound
clasping the stem, of leaves or bracts
joining up to form loops, usually of leaf-veins
wind-pollinated
of a silicula flattened at right-angles to the septum between the valves (cf. latiseptate)
of a plant flowering and dying in its first year (cf. biennial, perennial)
little ring, especially of thick-walled cells involved in opening fern sporangia
sac-like structure, bearing pollen
with a small broad point at the apex
club-shaped organ at the top of the spadix, often heat-producing and/or foetid
fleshy appendage of a seed, usually in gymnosperms which lack a fruit
awned, usually of leaves or bracts with an awn at the tip
small ear-like projection at the base of the leaf-blade (e.g Poaceae)
with auricles
stiff bristle-like projectionfromthe tip or back of the lemma (Poaceae), or froma fruit (usually the indurated style, e.g. Erodium) or less frequently from the tip of a leaf
place between the base of a leaf or petiole and the upper internode of the stem
form of placentation where the ovules arise from the centre of a multilocular ovary
borne in the axils of the leaves
tapering extension, in the form of a bird’s beak, usually of bracts or achenes
fleshy fruit, usually several seeded, without a stony layer surrounding the seeds (cf. drupe)
of a plant flowering and dying in its second year (cf. annual, perennial)
split deeply into two (cf. notched)
forked with two equal branches
twice successively pinnately divided
twice successively ternately divided
upper portion of the leaf of a grass or sedge
rounded swelling
leaf- or scale-like appendage, usually subtending a flower or inflorescence
small bract within a compound inflorescence
an underground bud, surrounded byfleshy leaves or scales and sometimes by a tunic
small bulb or tuber, arising in the axil of an aerial leaf or inflorescence
falling off at an early stage (cf. fugacious)
tufted
collection of sepals
bell-shaped
striated with longitudinal grooves
of an inflorescence, compacted in the form of a head
flat-bottomed cup-like inflorescence
a dry dehiscent fruit composed of more than one carpel
ovule-bearing structure, representative of the megasporophyll: an ovary consists of one or more carpels (cf. stamen)
fleshy outgrowth
specialised fruit where the pericarp is fused to the testa (Poaceae)
of a leaf attached above the base of the stem (cf. radical)
of flowers which open normally (cf. cleistogamous)
with regularly arranged hairs projecting from the margin
a green stem taking the place of a photosynthetic leaf (cf. phyllode)
lower portion of a petal which is tapered inwards to a narrow base
of flowers which never open and so are always self-pollinated (cf. chasmogamous)
of a modular structure such as a divided leaf or inflorescence
an incurved plane (cf. convex)
of the same kind growing together and becoming joined, though distinct in origin
an out-curved plane (cf. concave)
heart-shaped (as in a playing card or St Valentine´s Card), usually of the base of a leaf with two lobes
swollen section of underground stem of one year’s duration, usually erect and tunicated, topped by successive corms in future years (cf. tuber)
collection of petals
an unbranched group of flowers with indiviual stems shortening towards the top so that all the flowers are more or less at the same level
in the form of a corymb
flat-topped inflorescence, in the form of a corymb
of a margin with prominent rounded teeth (cf. dentate, serrate)
of a margin with very small rounded teeth (cf. denticulate, serrulate)
arranged in the form of a cross
tapered towards the base, especially of leaves
inflorescence in which successive pairs of flowers arise opposite each other, on either side of an older flower.
in the form of a cyme
of stems lying along the ground but with vertical growing points (cf. procumbent, prostrate)
having the base prolonged down the axis, as in leaves where the blade is continued as a wing on the petiole or stem
of opposite pairs in successive alternating planes (East-West, North-South, East-West etc.)
bent sharply downwards (cf. reflexed)
opening at maturity to shed its seeds or spores, of a fruit, capsule or sporangium
of a margin with prominent pointed teeth (cf. crenate, serrate)
of a margin with very small pointed teeth (cf. crenulate, serrulate)
of a flower where all but one of the stamens are fused into a tube (Fabaceae)
branching into two divisions
formed of two similar parts attached to each other by a small portion of their surface
of species with separate male and female individuals (literally two homes, cf. monoecious)
fracturing at the nodes, as of the axis of a spikelet at maturity (Poaceae)
floret from the disc of a capitulum (cf. marginal floret, ray-floret)
in the form of a disc
diverging at a wide angle
fleshy fruit, with one or more seeds surrounded by a stony layer eg cherry (cf. berry)
without glands
shallowly notched at the apex
of a species native to a restricted locality
leaf margin undivided, without teeth or other appendages
insect-pollinated
ring of small bracts subtending the calyx
of a flower with an inferior ovary
of stamens attached to the corolla
a plant growing on but not feeding off other plants
of a plant growing on but not feeding off other plants
protruding
sickle-shaped
bunch or bundle, usually with a short and indeterminate branching pattern
with or in the form of fascicles
stalk bearing an anther
thread-like
with the margin divided into a fringe
hollow and cylindrical, tube-like
leaf subtending the inflorescence of a grass
small flower, usually part of a large and/or dense inflorescence
stinking
many-seeded fruit formed from a single carpel
of placentation where the ovules are arranged on a central column in a unilocular fruit
complete leaf of a fern, including blade and stipe
withering or falling off very rapidly (cf. caducous)
the lower glume
the upper glume
bent abruptly making a ?knee” particularly of awns arising from the back of the lemma (Poaceae)
smooth, without hairs or bristles
bluish green
in the form of a globe, spherical
in the form of a globe, spherical
globe-shaped cluster of small flowers (Cuscuta)
bract-like structure subtending a spikelet (grasses) or floret (sedges)
specialised fruit of grasses, consisting of a caryopsis
of leaves with a triangular base
vascular plant with stems which are either entirely non-woody or only slightly woody towards the base (cf. shrub, tree)
bisexual flower or individual
clothed with long hairs
coarsely and stiffly hairy (cf. pilose)
thin and translucent
long tube between the neck of the corolla and an inferior ovary, formed by fusion of the lower parts of the sepals and petals (Oenothera)
of a flower with a superior ovary
of organs with their edges overlapping when in bud, like the tiles of a roof (cf. valvate)
hardened and toughened
protective flap covering a sorus
swollen or distended, as if blown up like a balloon
flowering branch or portion of stem above the last cauline leaf, including its branches, bracts and flowers
between other structures
bract contributing to an involucre (esp. Asteraceae)
collection of bracts subtending an inflorescence
a sharp-edged outer midrib, resembling the keel of a boat, usually of bracts or petals; a petal so formed (Fumaria, Fabaceae)
with an outer midrib in the form of a keel
lip formed from the corolla (Orchidaceae)
wooly
in the form of a lance
milky exudate from some plants
of a silicula flattened parallel to the septum between the valves (cf. angustiseptate)
loose not dense
green bract-like structure (grass floret)
of a leaf or floret with a ligule
strap-like structure: either from a split corolla tube (Asteraceae) or a membranous leaf appendage at the junction of the blade and sheath (Cyperaceae, Poaceae)
of a dehiscent fruit splitting down the middle of each loculus of the ovary
compartment of an anther containing pollen, or of an ovary containing ovules
floret floret from the circumference of a capitulum (cf. disc-floret, ray-floret)
sporangium producing four megaspores, from a single meiosis
large spore (visible to the naked eye) producing a female gametophyte
leaf bearing a megasporangium
one-seeded portion of a syncarpous ovary, split off at maturity
sporangium producing numerous microspores, from several meioses
microscopic spore producing a male gametophyte
leaf bearing a microsporangium
of a flower where all the stamens are fused into a tube (Fabaceae)
of a species with male and female flowers on the same plant (literally one home, cf. dioecious)
abruptly constricted to a short narrow point
shallowly divided by a V-shaped indentation (cf. bifid)
prefix meaning inverted (cf. obovate vs ovate)
inverted heart-shaped (as in a playing card or St Valentine’s Card), usually of the apex of a leaf with two lobes
rectangular but with rounded corners
egg-shaped, of leaves broadest above the middle
egg-shaped, of leaves broadest below the middle with a rounded tip
one or more carpels enclosing the ovules: it forms the fruit when ripe
egg-shaped, of leaves broadest below the middle but with an acute tip
in the three-dimensional form of a hen’s egg
structure enclosing the female gametophyte in flowering plants: it forms the seed when ripe
transparent bract-like structure (grass floret)
divided into a series of leaflets or lobes, emanating from a common point
strictly a branched racemose inflorescence, though often used to describe any branched inflorescence
(pl. ~ae) small elongated projection or microscopic hair
covered with papillae
collection of hairs, surrounding a floret or at the apex of an achene
form of placentation where the ovules arise from the margins of a unilocular ovary
stalk supporting a flower
on a short stalk
stalk supporting an inflorescence
of an inflorescence with a peduncle
of a circular disc, supported by a central stalk
suspended, hanging down
with components in multiples of five
of a plant surviving and flowering beyond its second year (cf. annual, biennial)
of a leaf or bract with its base united around the stem
collection of sepals and petals or tepals
fruit-wall, derived from the ovary
of a flower which is inserted around the ovary, so that the ovary is neither superior nor inferior
in the form of a coloured petal
leaf with a petiole
stalk supporting a leaf

with long soft hairs (cf. hispid, pubescent)

divided into a series of opposite-paired leaflets
divided into a series of opposite-paired lobes

subdivision of a pinnule
the female reproductive organ of the flower, consisting of ovary, style and stigma
arrangement of ovules within the ovary or seeds within the fruit
feathered, feather-like, especially of branched hairs (Asteraceae)
(pl. ~a) specialised stamen of orchids which is dispersed intact, along with its neighbour on the viscidium
a fleshy mass, divided in the centre into 5 or fewer cells around a central core, such as a apple
of stems lying loosely along the ground with horizontal growing points (cf. decumbent, prostrate)
of stems lying close to the ground with horizontal growing points (cf. decumbent, procumbent)
loosely coated in short soft hairs
bearing some short soft hairs
densely coated in short soft hairs (cf. pilose)
four-angled
unbranched inflorescence (group of flowers) with stalked flowers (cf. spike)
in the form of a raceme
main axis of a spikelet (Poaceae)
main axis of an inflorescence (Poaceae) or mid-rib of a pinnate leaf
of leaves arising from the base of the stem (cf. cauline)
ligulate marginal floret (cf. disc-floret, marginal floret)
bent sharply backwards (cf. deflexed)
kidney-shaped
marked with a network, usually of veins
rolled downwards
bearing rhizomes
underground stem
in the shape of a diamond in a pack of playing cards
ring of overlapping leaves, usually close to the ground
wrinkled
with small wrinkles
with a pouch
shaped like an arrowhead
dry indehiscent fruit with a wing extending from the pericarp
a non-photosynthetic plant, living off decayed matter
of a non-photosynthetic plant, living off decayed matter
slightly rough to the touch
rough to the touch

leaves reduced in size, seldom green or capable of performing the functions of leaves/organs resembling leaves in their position on the plant but differ in size, colour, texture and function eg. a pine cone scale
the flowering stem of a plant with only radical leaves
bearing a scape
thin, dry and papery, not usually green
of an inflorescence with flowers in two ranks, on one side of a coiled axis resembling a scorpion’s tail
in the form of a green sepal
of a margin with prominent saw-like teeth (cf. crenate, dentate)
of a margin with very small saw-like teeth (cf. crenulate, denticulate)
stalkless
shaped like a bristle but not necessarily rigid
the lower portion of an amplexicaul leaf, which surrounds the stem
woody plant branching abundantly from the base, usually less than 2m high (cf. herb, tree)
warf shrub, usually lees than 50 cm high (cf. shrub)
broad two-chambered fruit (Brassicaceae, cf. siliqua)
narrow two-chambered fruit (Brassicaceae, cf. silicula)
undivided
wavy in the same plane as the surface (cf. undulate)
the depression between two lobes or teeth
occurring singly rather than in groups, usually of flowers
localised gathering of sporangia
specialised column supporting numerous spirally arranged florets, often with a heat-producing or foetid club-shaped appendix at the top (Araceae)
large bract subtending and usually enclosing a developing inflorescence
spoon-shaped, broadening towards the tip, of leaves
in the form of a spike
unbranched inflorescence with spikelets or sessile flowers (cf. raceme)
one or more sessile florets, subtended by one or usually two glumes (Poaceae)
spore-bearing leaf
nectar-secreting tube extending from a sepal or petal
with a spur
male reproductive organ of the flower, representative of the microsporophyll and consisting of an anther and its filament (cf. carpel)
receptive surface for pollen, at the top of the style
fern petiole
small bract at the base of the petiole
a creeping stem produced by an otherwise erect or rosette-forming plant: it is usually above ground and a means of vegetative spread
bearing stolons
marked with long narrow depressions or ridges
growing upwards at a slight angle to the vertical
(pl. ~i) primitive cone made up of sporophylls
stalk conducting pollen tubes from the stigma to the ovule
of an inflorescence, more or less compacted in the form of a head
support from underneath
awl-shaped, narrow pointed and more or less flattened
the line of junction between two carpels
of an ovary consisting of several fused carpels
principal root, swollen with storage tissues
climbing organ formed from the whole or part of a stem, leaf or petiole, often the terminal portion of a pinnate leaf (Fabaceae)
segment of perianth which could be a sepal or petal and replaces both
cylindrical (of stems)
terminating the growth of a mid-rib or stem, as of a leaflet or inflorescence
of a leaf divided into three more or less equal parts (cf. trifoliate)
seed-coat, derived from the ovule
with components in multiples of four
coated in short cottony hairs
a dense covering of short cottony hairs
with semicircular ridges
a material which scatters transmitted light, so that images cannot be clearly viewed through it
a material which does not scatter transmitted light, so that images can be clearly viewed through it
woody plant with a main trunk, not normally branching less than 1m above the base, usually more than 2m high (cf. herb, shrub)
of a leaf divided into three leaflets which may or may not be equal (cf. ternate)
three-angled structure, angles obtuse (cf. triquetrous)
with components in multiples of three
thrice successively pinnately divided
three-angled structure, angles acute (cf. trigonous)
abruptly squared off, especially of a leaf-base
a swollen portion of a stem or root of one year’s duration, not giving rise to successive tubers in later years (cf. corm)
a small spherical or ovoid swelling
bearing tubercles
of a floret with corolla fused to form an intact tube
scarious covering around a bulb or corm
enveloped by a tunic
inflorescence of stalked flowers, the stalks emanating from the top of a stem but ending in a common plane so that the florets are all at the same level
hooked or crooked
wavy in a plane at right-angles to the surface (cf. sinuate)
one-sided
specialised flask-shaped structure, derived from a bract, enclosing the ovary of a sedge (Carex)
of perianth segments with their edges in contact but not overlapping in bud (cf. imbricate)
non-overlapping segment, often opening out on maturity as in a ripe capsule
whitish moisture-absorbing coating around aerial roots of epiphytic orchids
with long shaggy hairs
sticky base on which pollinia are dispersed
more than two organs of the same kind arising at the same level, usually around a central axis such as a stem
of organs arranged in a whorl
bilaterally symmetrical, usually of flowers (cf. actinomorphic)
Each of the parts of the calyx of a flower, enclosing the petals and typically green and leaflike.
A spike of unisex flowers within scales and lacking petals. Often drooping, dense and cylindrical.
